conclusion: Determine the critical angle for the glass-air interface
Index of refraction of the semi-cylinder: n = 2, Outside medium (air): n₀ = 1
sin θ_c = n₀ / n = 1 / 2, θ_c = arcsin(½) = 30°
A ray that reaches the curved surface from inside will escape only if its angle of incidence i does not exceed θ_c = 30°
Geometry of a ray inside the semi-cylinder
Choose a Cartesian cross-section with origin O at the centre of the circular cross-section, radius R
The flat entrance surface is the diameter AB (y = 0, –R ≤ x ≤ +R)
The curved surface is the half-circle x² + y² = R², y ≤ 0
Parallel light enters vertically downward; inside the glass every ray travels along the vector v = (0, –1)
Take the ray that enters at the point (x, 0); it intersects the circular boundary at P: P( x , –√(R² – x²) )
The inward normal at P is the radius OP: n = ( x , –√(R² – x²) )
Angle of incidence of the ray at P
cos i = ( v · n ) / |n| = √(R² – x²) / R
sin i = √(1 – cos² i) = x / R
The incidence angle is i = arcsin( x / R )
Condition for the ray to emerge
i ≤ θ_c ⇔ arcsin( x / R ) ≤ 30° ⇔ x / R ≤ ½ ⇔ |x| ≤ R/2
Only the rays that entered through the central strip |x| ≤ R/2 reach the curved surface with i ≤ 30° and can exit
Portion of the cylindrical surface that transmits light
Convert the coordinate limit |x| = R/2 to the corresponding angular limit on the circle
Let φ be the polar angle measured from the downward vertical, x = R sin φ; hence sin φ = x / R
